dt: {bc}an associate or coworker typically in a profession or in a civil or ecclesiastical office and often of similar rank or status {bc}a fellow worker or professional

quotes.t: Not since Cronkite's CBS mentor and {qword}colleague{/qword} Edward R. Murrow lifted Senator Joe McCarthy by the skunk tail for public inspection had one TV broadcast reflected such a fateful climate change in public opinion.
My {qword}colleague{/qword} Gene Sperling and I were standing over my speakerphone, but for all Mario Cuomo knew we were on our knees.
Nineteenth-century naturalist Thomas Henry Huxley, a {qword}colleague{/qword} of Charles Darwin, was the first to suggest that dinosaurs and birds were related.
… it gets noticed no more than an hour later by another {qword}colleague{/qword} of mine, whom I've never met personally but know to be an art historian …

et: Middle French {it}collegue{/it}, from Latin {it}collega{/it}, from {it}com-{/it} + {it}legare{/it} to depute {ma}{mat|legate|}{/ma}
shortdef: an associate or coworker typically in a profession or in a civil or ecclesiastical office and often of similar rank or status : a fellow worker or professional
